data.title: Nikon Plena
data.meta_description: Just got it in my mail box form Nikon with a message, "Get ready for something extraordinary". https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PSAunG9g6Z...
data.text:
suteetat

Offline

   

: Off

p.14 #4 · p.14 #4 · Nikon Plena

rand17 wrote:

Well... Japan has a track record of building quality equipment..kinda right up the with the Germans... so it is relevant..

Nikon manufacture lenses in Japan, Thailand and China. Japanese plant is now very small and only a fraction of lenses are still being made there. My guess would more likely be China as I was told by a good authority that it is not manufactured in Thailand.

To the best of my knowledge, I was told that the factory in Thailand, if you close your eyes, you might think that you are in Japan as Nikon brought over lots of Japanese employees to the factory here. Much of the assembly is also done by robots now.

Some glasses are made in Thailand while many are made in Japan and shipped over here. Nikon owns and operate all the factories and I assume that the same condition is also applicable to China. So personally, for Nikon lenses, I don't think that there is much difference as far as locations are concerned.

If you look at some provinces in Thailand where are there industrial parks with lots of Japanses companies, you will see loads of Japanese expats and in some area, you almost feel like you are in Japan. I think it is quite a bit different than the way the US or Europe operates factories overseas.

rand17

Offline

 

: Off

p.14 #5 · p.14 #5 · Nikon Plena

akul wrote:

Suteetat mentions it is not made in Thailand. It is a possibility it is made in Japan.

Well I now believe it is made in Thailand...B&H put out a video and the can see made in Thailand on the lens hood..I have never seen a lens hood made one place and a lens made elsewhere... anyway...Just hate to see companies so desperate to cut cost and stoop down to inferior manufacturing... yeah yeah....here come the people with the who cares where it's made mindset...but one still can not overlook the high quality of Nikon products made is Japan..Hell take some lenses apart and compare them.. you will see the difference immediately...

rand17

p.14 #9 · p.14 #9 · Nikon Plena

SiMuMe wrote:

This article may disappoint you, a lot.

Yeah, considering that the Z mount lenses are pretty much all superior to their F mount counterparts, and many are best in class, including those made in Thailand and China, I am firmly in the 'it doesn't matter' camp.

The 14-24/2.8 is absolutely phenomenal, the 24-120 is the best standard zoom I've used (all around, taking into account range and versatility) and the 105 macro is the best macro lens I've used. All manufactured in Thailand. I've used a LOT of lenses, from all manufacturers.

rand17

 

: Off

p.14 #10 · p.14 #10 · Nikon Plena

akul wrote:

You know Suteetat is from Thailand? Your belief, or opinion is yours, and I am not to challenge your view, but I would prefer if you could express your opinion in not so provocative manner. Just my 2 cents.

Luka

Ok he's from Thailand!! Thats awesome! Love to hear that.. and Provocative??.. you mean I should overlook the cut back on quality of Nikon products and make everything colorful?...not really a strong opinion but more a disheartening situation.. again pull some lenses apart and see for yourself..

Jman13 wrote:

Yeah, considering that the Z mount lenses are pretty much all superior to their F mount counterparts, and many are best in class, including those made in Thailand and China, I am firmly in the 'it doesn't matter' camp.

The 14-24/2.8 is absolutely phenomenal, the 24-120 is the best standard zoom I've used (all around, taking into account range and versatility) and the 105 macro is the best macro lens I've used. All manufactured in Thailand. I've used a LOT of lenses, from all manufacturers.

True!! these new lenses do take cute little snap shots when new... no doubt!.. but you maybe disappointed when the longevity of these lenses breakdown do to all the plastics deteriorating and breaking down.. as designed to!.. hence the 10 year recycle emblem on the lens...

p.14 #12 · p.14 #12 · Nikon Plena

rand17 wrote:

Provocative??.. you mean I should overlook the cut back on quality of Nikon products and make everything colorful?...not really a strong opinion but more a disheartening situation.. again pull some lenses apart and see for yourself..

In my opinion, the word, Third World is 1. Obsolete expression with prejudice 2. Inappropriate in public forum 3. Insulting. This forum attracts members from all over the world, and quite international. If that explanation is not enough for you, I wont have anything more to say.

Luka

kwalsh

Offline

   

: Off

p.14 #14 · p.14 #14 · Nikon Plena

rand17 wrote:

but you maybe disappointed when the longevity of these lenses breakdown do to all the plastics deteriorating and breaking down.. as designed to!.. hence the 10 year recycle emblem on the lens...

You dont even know what that symbol means and of course are drawing erroneous conclusions about it:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China_RoHS

Not surprising at all really that if you cant understand something so basic and trivial to look up that your posts would be full of other flagrant cluelessness. You are welcome to enjoy soaking in your jingoistic cesspool of ignorance, but dont expect anyone else to join you.

Jman13

Offline

     

: On

p.14 #15 · p.14 #15 · Nikon Plena

rand17 wrote:

True!! these new lenses do take cute little snap shots when new... no doubt!.. but you maybe disappointed when the longevity of these lenses breakdown do to all the plastics deteriorating and breaking down.. as designed to!.. hence the 10 year recycle emblem on the lens...

1) You're being very condescending, and it's not really appropriate.

2) That logo does not mean that you need to recycle it in 10 years. That logo means that no hazardous substances will be emitted by the product for at least 10 years. And unless you have any actual evidence that these products have less longevity than prior lenses, this is simply scaremongering. The regulation that required marking of this logo came into effect in 2016, so of course older lenses didn't have it. F mount lenses manufactured after this regulation came into effect are also marked with the 10 logo.

Vinnie_VdB

Offline

  

: Off

p.14 #17 · p.14 #17 · Nikon Plena

rand17 wrote:

Then why the move to a third world country if everything is the same and there using there same people?

Japan has a problem with an aging population and cannot find the people for the job, mass production is not possible anymore.

Sure enough are the wages lower of factory workers in Thailand and as Suteetat rightfully highlights is Thailand an economic motor for Japanese multinationals.

I go several times a year to Thailand for business and the way you express your view is the one that has his head so far up his *** that I can only advise you to look a bit further that your hometown or even state, just a bit just so you can have an opinion based on facts and experience.
